description:
Scaptodrosophila lebanonensis is a species of fruit fly that belongs to the genus Scaptodrosophila. It was first discovered and described from specimens collected in Lebanon.

Scaptodrosophila lebanonensis is a small fly, typically measuring around 2-3 millimeters in length. The species has a characteristic body shape and coloration common to many fruit flies, with a rounded abdomen and brownish-colored wings. The eyes of the fly are large and compound, and the antennae are relatively short.

Genetically, Scaptodrosophila lebanonensis is classified within the family Drosophilidae, which includes a diverse group of small, often cosmopolitan flies commonly known as "vinegar flies" or "pomace flies." The species is believed to be native to the Middle Eastern region, where it likely feeds on decaying plant matter and ripe fruits.

Like other fruit flies, Scaptodrosophila lebanonensis has a relatively short life cycle, with eggs hatching into larvae that undergo metamorphosis before emerging as adults. The flies play a role in the decomposition of organic matter and may also be useful as a model organism in various scientific studies.
